meeting_annotations.transcript: Well I just wanted to start by saying that I'm really glad that we're having this conversation with such a big room as well. So we work like in the proteomics field so we kind of you know, I guess do like the basic stuff of like you know putting our data sets on pride so that you know anyone can look at them. You know in that sense we're not doing anything too revolutionary. Like we're way behind I think what structural biologists have been doing. Um but I'm like just really interested in general in this idea of like you know how do we sort of make all of like the data including like the so-called negative results that we you know don't know how to interpret like available and indexable so that we can sort of like fuel the next like AI breakthrough because I feel like the fact that structural biologists had their house in order so well you know we just kind of have you know this like amazing victory to like savor for it and like you know personally I would wish that we could say the same thing for proteomics and I'm sure many of the people here would you know be able to make the extrapolation to their field as well.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erika Matunis
